headline: Coinbase Hires Former Goldman Sachs Partner To Manage Key Pillars Of 'Everything Exchange' Strategy
summary: Coinbase (NASDAQ:COIN) has hired former Goldman Sachs (NYSE:GS) Partner Liz Martin as it looks to expand beyond cryptocurrency trading. Martin is joining Coinbase as vice president of product, overseeing its markets and derivatives divisions, the exchange said in a statement to Benzinga on Thursday. “She will lead Coinbase’s exchanges, drive the next phase of growth for the company’s derivatives business, and manage its global markets team – all key pillars of Coinbase’s ‘Everything Exchange’ st

headline: Goldman Advances Overhaul With Sale of Polish TFI Stake to ING
summary: GS agrees to divest its Polish asset management unit stake to ING, completing ING's move to full ownership pending 2026 approvals.

headline: Goldman Poised for a Major M&A Milestone This Year: What's Driving?
summary: GS is seizing a third of global M&A this year as mega-deals surge, setting up one of its strongest advisory performances in decades.

headline: MP Materials stock surges on Pentagon-backed deal to develop rare earth refinery in Saudi Arabia
summary: The agreement will expand MP's global footprint and is structured to "ensure U.S. oversight and alignment with national security objectives," the company said.

headline: Small business finance firm SAPI lands $80m funding boost
summary: A small business financing platform co-founded by a Goldman Sachs alumnus will this week unveil an $80m (£61m) funding boost as it seeks to expand its international presence.  Sky News understands that SAPI has secured $75m in debt financing and $5m of equity in a round led by Hudson Cove, a US-based alternative credit asset manager.  Co-founded by Mai Le, formerly of Goldman Sachs, and Alexis van Lennep, who used to work for AlixPartners, SAPI has advanced tens of millions of pounds to small businesses, the vast majority of which are either immigrant- or female-owned.

Co-founded by Mai Le, formerly of Goldman Sachs, and Alexis van Lennep, who used to work for AlixPartners, SAPI has advanced tens of millions of pounds to small businesses, the vast majority of which are either immigrant- or female-owned.

headline: Goldman’s Waldron Sees More Market Pullback, Subprime Loan Risk
summary: “It strikes me the market could pull back further from here,” Waldron said in an interview on the sidelines of the Bloomberg New Economy Forum in Singapore on Wednesday.  A selloff in the world’s largest technology companies has reignited a debate on AI, and whether it is generating enough revenue or profit to justify the massive spending on infrastructure.  “You’re seeing in the markets right now a pullback, which I think is healthy — markets have run quite a bit this year,” he said on Bloomberg Television.
